p: From the foregoing, it appears that Ae. albopictus, while being ancestrally a forest-breeding mosquito like its close relatives, among these relatives it is the most closely adapted to forest margins (ecotone), the transition from forest to degraded or secondary forests, open grasslands or scrub. Aedes aegypti in Africa is similar [ 47]. This may have pre-adapted these two Aedes, among all their congeners in Asia and Africa, to come into contact with human settlements and thus to adapt to this new niche, human settlements.
